Title: "Optimizing Search Results in Azure Cognitive Search: Field Selection and Composition"
Text:
C:\Users\adamh\Downloads\azure-search.pdfAsciiFoldingTokenFilter",            "preserveOriginal":true         }      ]   } See alsoHow to work with search results inAzure Cognitive SearchArticle•08/31/2023This article explains how to work with a query response in Azure Cognitive Search. Thestructure of a response is determined by parameters in the query itself, as described inSearch Documents (REST) or SearchResults Class (Azure for .NET).
Parameters on the query determine:Field selectionCount of matches found in the index for the queryPaging resultsNumber of results in the response (up to 50, by default)Sort orderHighlighting of terms within a result, matching on either the whole or partial termin the bodyResults are tabular, composed of fields of either all "retrievable" fields, or limited to justthose fields specified in the $select parameters.
Rows are the matching documents.You can choose which fields are in search results. While a search document might have alarge number of fields, typically only a few are needed to represent each document inresults. On a query request, append $select=<field list> to specify which "retrievable"fields should appear in the response.
Pick fields that offer contrast and differentiation among documents, providing sufficientinformation to invite a click-through response on the part of the user. On an e-commerce site, it might be a product name, description, brand, color, size, price, andrating. For the built-in hotels-sample index, it might be the "select" fields in thefollowing example:HTTPResult compositionPOST /indexes/hotels-sample-index/docs/search?api-version=2020-06-30     {        "search": "sandy beaches",      "select": "HotelId, HotelName, Description, Rating, Address/City"Occasionally, the substance and not the structure of results are unexpected.
